comments.commentBody: Life expectancy for a man who reaches 20 today is far greater than 60.  We didn't have cures or even treatments for any of the diseases that tend to occur more frequently as one ages such as heart disease, cancer, and, the really big one even in adults, infectious diseases.

"Americans throughout the period were lucky if they survived into middle age." Not really; if they survived infancy or early childhood, their odds were not that different than today. In 1860, the average life expectancy of a man at age 20 was about 60 years. All those men dying in their early twenties was nowhere near the norm. Those who grew up in cities were either dead or immune to most diseases by the time they reached military age; those from rural areas were much more likely to become exposed for the first time in the army, and their mortality rates show it.

I've lived in or worked in about a dozen different countries from Asia through Europe, East and West, and the thing that has always struck me is this false belief Americans have that everyone wants to move here. I find the people who want to move to the U.S. very rare. Most have a very distorted idea of what America is gained from watching our movies. In Algeria in 1970 people there thought the wild west was still populated with cowboys carrying six-shooters,, really. I've had a home in a small village in Eastern Europe for 35 years and although one of the local families accepted our invitation to visit us in the States, they developed no desire to stay, and none of our neighbors have any interest in emigrating to the U.S. We need to get over ourselves and fix this country. It is broken.

"Playing the race card" is making the argument that someone perceived to belong to one ethnic group is perceived to be inferior to members of another ethnic group. Racism is a tool used to keep working people from working together to improve their standard of living. "Immigration increases diversity" is not "playing the race card." And I don't know where you even heard that. Sounds like trollage to me.

What is missing from all of these debates, due to short term collective memory loss, is that the uptick in enforcement and the increase talk of removing "illegals" is the direct result of 9/11 and the sudden deterioration of our economy.

The attack on the Hispanic population is real and cannot be denied. Border Patrol drive around hunting brown skinned people, not usually descendants of other ethnicities. And they do their work in Hispanic communities, not in Chinatown, etc.

The Hispanic scapegoat is long overburdened. Waiting in line is an extreme fallacy when a family of American citizens wait over 20 years in an attempt to bring their daughter here legally.

It is the stressed middle class and more economically deprived who are clamoring for the removal of the Hispanics, pushed by talk show radio and incomplete reporting by other sources. Removing Hispanics will not correct our economic problems and may do quite the opposite. Study the reports of the CBO and the President's Council of Economic Advisors, both Republican and Democratic. Only pseudo think tanks, such as FAIR, CIS, and the Heritage Foundation disagree with this statement.

What bothers me most about the arguments in favor of ending deportation is that they are often made while playing the race card: "immigration increases diversity".

Somehow, the immigration debate in this country has become the hispanic illegal immigration debate. Furthermore, 'illegal immigration advocates' make the debate a moral, racial issue, when the fact of the matter is that illegal immigrants are generally not the world's neediest, and are not racially diverse. What about African and Asian intending immigrants? Isn't it wrong that so many people should get a head start on their 'path to immigration' when millions must wait in line? Beyond that, our country already has by far and away the most liberal immigration policy of any developed nation. The desire to control immigration is not at all contrary to our country's history.

I've worked in immigration, and around the world people are desperate to immigrate to the U.S. In my opinion, anyone who has a realistic grasp of economics and politics would agree that we cannot simply let everyone who wants to immigrate to the U.S. do so. The line has to be drawn somewhere, and it's not beyond the people who have the geographical luck to be able to sneak into the country.

Sorry, but I know H1b visa holders who get a bit evasive about their legal status because their visas have expired. I think that in a lawful society the laws applicable to visa expiration should also be enforced.

The State Department under all administrations is routinely criticized for not "achieving" world peace and universal love among dozens of foreign nations eager to annihilate each other. But the primary assignment of the State Dept. is to represent American interests in the international arena, and where possible, it can act as an intermediary in negotiations between adversarial countries, but the responsibility to achieve resolution rests with the contestants, not the State Department.

I am wary of Hillary Clinton (as I am of all politicians) but like many liberals will quickly vote for her over any of the strange men the GOP dumps onto the political stage, men whom I regard, without sarcasm, as not being of sound mental health, much less are they socially enlightened. I may (and do) disagree with various policy positions or executive tactics of Obama or Clinton, but they are not hopelessly demented. I cannot say the same of Cruz or Perry or Ryan.

My primary criterium is that a candidate be reasonably sane, starting with their ability to acknowledge reality and a provable fact. A ridiculously low bar, but one the Republican candidates trip over routinely.

David Ropeik, Main Post and reply to Shellenberger/Nordhaus, April 16th

Dear Mr. Ropeik,

The public is NOT indifferent to climate change. Twenty-five years of constant media fear-mongering has scared the pants off of just about everybody who is not in a coma.

The public simply has made a rational decision that the solutions being offered to the problem are either 1) a form of collective hair shirt, or 2) high-tech gimcrackery not ready for prime time.

Earth Hour. 3-bin recycling. Ethanol from corn. Biodiesel grown on clear-cut rain forest. Wind farms chewing up bats and birds. Solar thermal frying birds in flight. The list goes on.

Each of these hyped to the skies by the snake-oil salesmen of the environmental movement. Each of them laughably ineffective at a high price.

Unless leaders have dictatorial powers, they MUST mobilize their followers by persuasion, passion and appeal to rational self-interest.

So the leadership you advocate requires that such leaders offer the public an EFFECTIVE alternative to the status quo.

Yet what policies do we hear advocated from the environmental movement?

Engineered economic depressions to suppress GHG emissions growth. Carbon offsets for the rich. Cap and trade. "Reparations" from developed countries to developing countries. Bankrupting viable industries to subsidize Solyndra style start-ups.

Alexander the Great and Douglas MacArthur couldn't motivate a short-handed patrol of Boy Scouts with a program like that.

I'm at the time in my life when peers are either digging in for the long haul of urban life, or choosing the suburbs. I can see pros and cons of each.

My husband and I don't have kids, so the school situation is out of the equation. We enjoy our short commutes, the opportunities offered in our diverse, walkable neighborhood, having parks nearby, and not owning a car. We'll be in the city for a while. Forever? I'm not sure, but we definitely have no moving plans on the horizon.

I agree with Mr. McCormack in Westchester County who said, “What we’re seeing is not so much an exodus as a later arrival.” Of my friends who were committed urbanites in their early 30s about half have decamped for the suburbs, and the reasoning seems to boil down to two things: more affordable, more spacious housing, and better schools that don't require so much effort and energy to access.

All of these friends swear that "they'll be back" in the city once the kids are grown. We'll see.

I do wonder if the suburban towns seeing a drop in 25- to 34-year-olds also have a shortage of more affordable starter homes.

"Others who accept the data dispute Mr. Roberts’s explanations, pointing out that prices in some Manhattan and Brooklyn neighborhoods are even higher than those in the more expensive suburbs."

Well that certainly isn't rocket science. All you have to do is read real estate ads to get an idea how many square feet your money will buy in Manhattan or Brooklyn vs. better suburbs of Westchester or Connecticut. I have also been looking at real estate ads for London and comparing them with historic country properties in England and it is really quite jaw dropping to compare what money buys in the countryside versus what it does (or doesn't) buy in London.
East Hampton & Southampton subsidize a few farms. The cost runs into the $millions.

Suburbs demand a wholly car dependent life, as well as a high proportion of asphalted land to support the houses dispersed across the landscape. An asphalted earth is a dead earth. Per the American Farmland Trust, an acre of farmland is lost to suburban development every minute. http://www.farmland.org/default.asp

Won't be much for dinner if suburbs remain wildly popular. Historically, Long Island was rich with farms, but most have been driven out. A far smarter future should include plans to ring cities with farms to provide fresh, healthy food with a lowered carbon investment. NOW is the time to think outside the box to plan a more resilient future for our children.

There's lots of reasons-First, I can't afford to buy a home in the NJ town I grew up in! My parents bought a new home in 1964. My father took the train to NY City every day. My mom worked part time AND raised 3 boys. We went on two or three nice vacations every year. My dad was an engineer! I'm an engineer. I CANNOT do what he did now! Secondly, the cost of commuting (not including time) is ridiculous. Third, employers expect you to work late EVERY time they ask you-and they do NOT care that you have a home life. Fourth, it's cheaper to rent an apartment in Brooklyn. With all that said, I would love to move back to New Jersey. I HATE LIVING IN THE CITY!

"Wildly carbon wasteful?" People are wasteful. Not where they live. The cities are not as carbon efficient as you all like to believe. It's a lot of "greenwashing."
How can the entire population live in urban areas? It's impossible, illogical, and inefficient.

"Green space"? you mean a park? Instead of Central Park, which is a joke of a park to out of towners, try Van Cortlandt Park or Pelham Bay Park, in the Bronx,  now those are urban parks, real parks... oh i forgot you hate to commute- oh well.

No need to own a car, no lawns to mow, minimal commuting time, no rivers to cross, and a vast offering of culture on your doorstep.  Financially it's tough but the city has a lot to offer.  Green space?...Central Park which is awesome.

The memorials to our Civil War dead in town squares throughout the Northeast bear testimony to the extraordinary sacrifice of those who Lincoln called "our honored dead." The distinction between deaths caused by diseases and those by direct combat is purely academic. Slaughter is slaughter!
